title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or near Indian lands with a high unemployment rate of 45 percent. These individuals own over 197,000 businesses, generating more than $34 billion in revenue. The service industry is the largest sector, followed by construction and retail trade. The number of businesses owned by these groups increased by 84 percent from 1992 to 1997. The construction industry accounted for 15.7 percent of receipts, followed by retail trade at 13.4 percent. Businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives saw significant growth in both numbers and gross receipts compared to all businesses. The Small Business Development Center program proved cost-effective, generating additional tax revenues of $468 million in 1998. The Small Business Development Center program is cost-effective, generating $468 million in additional tax revenues in 1998, six times the program's cost to the Federal Government. Small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians receiving services have a higher survival rate. Business counseling is critical on Indian lands where similar services are scarce and expensive. Increased counseling under the program has been shown to reduce barriers for small businesses. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands, foster economic development, assist in creating and expanding small businesses owned by tribe members, and provide management assistance. Business counseling and technical assistance are crucial on Indian lands where services are limited and costly. Increased counseling through the Small Business Development Center program has been proven to reduce default rates for lending programs. The Act aims to stimulate economic development on Indian lands by assisting in creating and expanding small businesses owned by tribe members. It provides management, technical, and research assistance, seeks advice from Tribal Councils, and ensures full access to business counseling and technical assistance. Small Business Development Center assistance is provided to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Small Business Act amended to provide additional grant for outreach and development on Indian lands for small business startups owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Eligible States can apply for this grant. The Small Business Act has been amended to offer grants for outreach and development of small business startups owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians on Indian lands. Eligible States with a population of at least 1 percent comprised of these groups can apply for the grant by submitting an application to the Administration. The Small Business Act offers grants for outreach and development of small business startups owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians on Indian lands. Grant applicants must submit an application to the Administration including information on goals, training capabilities, location of the Small Business Development Center site, and required grant amount. The Small Business Act provides grants for small business startups owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant applicants must include details such as the location of the Small Business Development Center site, required grant funding, and consultation with local Tribal Councils. Applicants must comply with all requirements except for matching funds. The Small Business Act provides grants for small business startups owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant applicants must comply with all requirements except for matching funds. The maximum grant amount is $300,000 per fiscal year. The Administration will issue final regulations after consulting with the recognized Association. The Small Business Act provides grants for small business startups owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant applicants must comply with all requirements except for matching funds. The Administration will issue final regulations after consulting with the recognized Association, establishing standards for educational, technical, and support services provided by Small Business Development Centers receiving assistance, and work plan requirements for these centers. The Small Business Act provides grants for small business startups owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. The Administration will establish standards for work plans required by Small Business Development Centers receiving assistance under this paragraph. Definitions for "Indian lands" are provided in this section. The term 'Indian tribe' refers to any band, nation, or organized group of Indians in the contiguous United States and the Metlakatla Indian Community, eligible for services under the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. The term 'Indian tribe' refers to any band, nation, or organized group of Indians in the contiguous United States, including the Metlakatla Indian Community, eligible for services under the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. An 'Indian tribe member' is a member of an Indian tribe, excluding Alaska Natives. 'Alaska Native' is defined as per the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to an individual who is a US citizen and a descendant of the aboriginal people who exercised sovereignty in Hawaii before 1778. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to a descendant of the aboriginal people who exercised sovereignty in Hawaii before 1778. Tribal organization is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. $7,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2006-2008 for this purpose. Funding limitations apply. Authorization of $7,000,000 for fiscal years 2006-2008 for Native Hawaiian programs with funding limitations specified. The Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers to seek advice from tribal organizations on how to assist Indian tribe members and where to locate satellite centers for assistance.
